from sortedcontainers import SortedList
class Solution:
    def maximumSegmentSum(self, nums: List[int], removeQueries: List[int]) -> List[int]:
        s = SortedList(); n = len(nums)
        sumList = SortedList()
        p = [0]*(len(nums)+1)
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            p[i+1] += p[i] + nums[i]
        s.add([0,n-1,p[-1]])
        sumList.add(p[-1])
        ans = []
        for i in removeQueries:
            idx = s.bisect_left([i,-1,-1])
            if idx==len(s) or s[idx][0]>i:
                idx-=1
            start,end,segSum = s[idx]
            sumList.remove(segSum)
            leftSum = p[i]-p[start]
            rightSum = p[end+1] - p[i+1]
            s.remove(s[idx])
            if i!=start:
                sumList.add(leftSum)
                s.add([start,i-1,leftSum])
            if i!=end:
                sumList.add(rightSum)
                s.add([i+1,end,rightSum])
            if not sumList:
                ans.append(0)
            else:
                ans.append(sumList[-1])
        return ans
            
        
```

solutions.content:
A simple good solution for starting from back and then merging the chains.

```
def find_parent(j, ds):
    if ds[j] < 0:
        return j
    # it might be possible that we have a chain, so we need to
    # recurse
    parent_index = find_parent(ds[j], ds)
    # to optimise the chain, we save the final parent:)
    ds[j] = parent_index
    return parent_index

def merge(left, b, ds):
    # Make the left chain the parent chain
    p_left = find_parent(left, ds)
    p2 = find_parent(b, ds)
    # add the right chain value to the left chain
    ds[p_left] += ds[p2]
    # connect the right chain to point to the parent of left chain
    ds[p2] = p_left

class Solution:
    def maximumSegmentSum(self, nums: List[int], removeQueries: List[int]) -> List[int]:
        N = len(nums)
        res = [0] * N
        INT_MAX = float('inf')
        ds = [INT_MAX]*N
        
        for i in range(N-1, 0, -1):
            j = removeQueries[i]
            # create a single node chain
            ds[j] = -nums[j]
            # if there is a chain to the left, then merge them
            if (j > 0 and ds[j - 1] != INT_MAX):
                merge(j-1, j, ds)
            # if there is the chain to the right then merge them
            if (j < N - 1 and ds[j + 1] != INT_MAX):
                merge(j, j + 1, ds)
            # check if the merged chain are bigger than existing biggest
            res[i - 1] = max(res[i], -ds[find_parent(j, ds)]);
        return res

```

    p_left = find_parent(left, ds)
    p2 = find_parent(b, ds)
    # add the right chain value to the left chain
    ds[p_left] += ds[p2]
    # connect the right chain to point to the parent of left chain
    ds[p2] = p_left

class Solution:
    def maximumSegmentSum(self, nums: List[int], removeQueries: List[int]) -> List[int]:
        N = len(nums)
        res = [0] * N
        INT_MAX = float('inf')
        ds = [INT_MAX]*N
        
        for i in range(N-1, 0, -1):
            j = removeQueries[i]
            # create a single node chain
            ds[j] = -nums[j]
            # if there is a chain to the left, then merge them
            if (j > 0 and ds[j - 1] != INT_MAX):
                merge(j-1, j, ds)
            # if there is the chain to the right then merge them
            if (j < N - 1 and ds[j + 1] != INT_MAX):
                merge(j, j + 1, ds)
            # check if the merged chain are bigger than existing biggest
            res[i - 1] = max(res[i], -ds[find_parent(j, ds)]);
        return res

```

```\nclass Solution {\npublic:\n    vector<long long> maximumSegmentSum(vector<int>& nums, vector<int>& removeQueries) {\n        const long long n=nums.size();\n        vector<vector<long long>>groupinfo(n,{-1,-1,-1});\n\t\t//for i\'th index\n\t\t// groupinfo[i][0] is startingIndex\n\t\t// groupinfo[i][1] is endingIndex\n\t\t// groupinfo[i][2] is sum\n        vector<long long>res(n);\n        long long mx=0;\n        for(long long i=n-1;i>=0;--i){\n            res[i]=mx;\n            long long index=removeQueries[i];\n            long long l,r,sum;\n            if(index!=0 && index!=n-1 && groupinfo[index-1][0]!=-1 && groupinfo[index+1][0]!=-1){\n                sum=groupinfo[index-1][2]+groupinfo[index+1][2]+nums[index];\n                l=groupinfo[index-1][0];\n                r=groupinfo[index+1][1];\n                groupinfo[l][1]=r;\n                groupinfo[l][2]=sum;\n                groupinfo[r][0]=l;\n                groupinfo[r][2]=sum;\n            }else if(index!=0 && groupinfo[index-1][0]!=-1){\n                l=groupinfo[index-1][0];\n                sum=groupinfo[l][2]+nums[index];\n                groupinfo[l][1]=index;\n                groupinfo[l][2]=sum;\n                groupinfo[index][0]=l;\n                groupinfo[index][1]=index;\n                groupinfo[index][2]=sum;\n            }else if(index!=n-1 && groupinfo[index+1][0]!=-1){\n                r=groupinfo[index+1][1];\n                sum=groupinfo[r][2]+nums[index];\n                groupinfo[r][0]=index;\n                groupinfo[r][2]=sum;\n                groupinfo[index][0]=index;\n                groupinfo[index][1]=r;\n                groupinfo[index][2]=sum;\n            }else{\n                groupinfo[index][0]=groupinfo[index][1]=index;\n                groupinfo[index][2]=nums[index];\n                sum=nums[index];\n            }\n            mx=max(mx,sum);\n        }\n        return res;\n    }\n};\n```

```
from collections import defaultdict
class Solution:
    def maximumSegmentSum(self, nums: List[int], removeQueries: List[int]) -> List[int]:
        segments = defaultdict(lambda:(0,0))
        cur_max = 0
        res = []
        for q in reversed(removeQueries):
            lv, left_len = segments[q-1]
            rv, right_len = segments[q+1]
            curv, cur_len = lv+rv+nums[q], left_len+right_len+1 
            segments[q-left_len] = (curv, cur_len)
            segments[q+right_len] = (curv, cur_len)
            cur_max = max(cur_max, curv)
            res.append(cur_max)
        res.pop()
        res.reverse()
        res.append(0)
        return res

solutions.content:
**Main Idea**:
+ The problem changes to **find maximum segment sum** after **inserting elements** with positions **from last to begin** of removeQueries.
+ Data structure for intervals **(ai, bi)** where **hs[ai]=bi**, **he[bi]=ai**, with sum values **s[(ai, bi)]** and sorted set **seg[(si, (ai, bi))]**

**Examples**:
```
[1, 2, 5, 6, 1] [0, 3, 2, 4, 1]
+ 1 sums: [2] - s: [(2, (1, 1))] - hs: {1: 1} - he: {1: 1} - ans: [0, 2]
+ 4 sums: [2, 1] - s: [(1, (4, 4)), (2, (1, 1))] - hs: {1: 1, 4: 4} - he: {1: 1, 4: 4} - ans: [0, 2, 2]
+ 2 sums: [1, 7] - s: [(1, (4, 4)), (7, (1, 2))] - hs: {1: 2, 4: 4} - he: {4: 4, 2: 1} - ans: [0, 2, 2, 7]
+ 3 sums: [14] - s: [(14, (1, 4))] - hs: {1: 4} - he: {4: 1} - ans: [0, 2, 2, 7, 14]
ans: [14, 7, 2, 2, 0]
====================

[3, 2, 11, 1] [3, 2, 1, 0]
+ 0 sums: [3] - s: [(3, (0, 0))] - hs: {0: 0} - he: {0: 0} - ans: [0, 3]
+ 1 sums: [5] - s: [(5, (0, 1))] - hs: {0: 1} - he: {1: 0} - ans: [0, 3, 5]
+ 2 sums: [16] - s: [(16, (0, 2))] - hs: {0: 2} - he: {2: 0} - ans: [0, 3, 5, 16]
ans: [16, 5, 3, 0]
====================
```
**Code**:
```
from sortedcontainers import SortedSet
class Solution:
    def maximumSegmentSum(self, nums: List[int], removeQueries: List[int]) -> List[int]:
        seg = SortedSet([])
        hs = {}
        he = {}
        s = {}
        ans = [0]
        cnt = 0
        removeQueries = removeQueries[::-1][:-1]
        for pi in removeQueries:
            ai, bi, si = pi, pi, nums[pi]
            if hs.get(bi+1) is not None:
                ki = (bi+1, hs[bi+1])
                ti = s[ki]
                seg.discard((ti, ki)); s.pop(ki)
                bi = hs.pop(bi+1)
                si += ti
            if he.get(ai-1) is not None:
                ki = (he[ai-1], ai-1)
                ti = s[ki]
                seg.discard((ti, ki)); s.pop(ki)
                ai = he.pop(ai-1)
                si += ti
            hs[ai], he[bi] = bi, ai
            s[(ai, bi)] = si
            seg.add((si, (ai, bi)))
            ans.append(seg[-1][0])
            print("+", pi, "sums:", list(s.values()), "- s:", list(seg), "- hs:", hs, "- he:", he, "- ans:", ans)
        
        ans = ans[::-1]
        print("ans:", ans)
        print("="*20)
        return ans

```

solutions.content:
As far as N=1E5 problems go, Python O(N^2) solutions generally don't work. However, a list insertion in the inner loop is sometimes okay, and then it depends on the complexity of the test cases. This is not a winning approach, but having no good ideas, I went with a brute-force algorithm. This clocked in at under 7 seconds (out of 10 seconds maximum):

```
def maximumSegmentSum(self, nums: List[int], removeQueries: List[int]) -> List[int]:
	psums = [0]  # Left-pad psums.
	for num in nums:
		psums.append(psums[-1] + num)
	n = len(nums)            
	ans = []
	removals = [-1, n]  # Pad removals.
	segmentHeap = []  # Store -score, start, end.

	def addSegmentToHeap(startIncl, endIncl):
		if startIncl <= endIncl:
			score = psums[endIncl + 1] - psums[startIncl]
			heapq.heappush(segmentHeap, (-score, startIncl, endIncl))

	for i in range(n):
		removal = removeQueries[i]
		iRem = bisect.bisect_left(removals, removal)
		removals.insert(iRem, removal)  # Fast O(N) operation.
		# Removal splits a segment. Add both new segments to heap.
		addSegmentToHeap(removals[iRem - 1] + 1, removal - 1)
		addSegmentToHeap(removal + 1, removals[iRem + 1] - 1)
		found = False
		while segmentHeap:
			negScore, topLo, topHi = segmentHeap[0]
			iTopLo = bisect.bisect_left(removals, topLo - 1)
			# Return top segment if it is fresh. If it is stale (due to
			# a split) pop it and continue.
			if removals[iTopLo + 1] == topHi + 1:
				ans.append(-negScore)
				found = True
				break
			heapq.heappop(segmentHeap)
		if not found:
			ans.append(0)

	return ans
```

This may not be a solution that will get you hired, but if you point out that the constant on `removals.insert(iRem, removal)` is very small, a good interviewer will consider that your ability to think beyond just runtime complexity makes you a decent candidate.

content.content: Hint:\n1. traverse from back to front of removeQueries and use "Union find" to add each element to the group\n2.  keep track the "max segmention sum" when doing Union

The hints, which tell to make a data structure for storing removal points (binary search tree) and use a heap to find maximum sums, lead to an inefficient solution that doesn't pass in Python.

This was my initial idea. I implemented the following algorithm:
1. Create a prefix sum array for `nums`
2. Walk the remove queries forward
    1. For each query find the nearest left and right queries in the BST
    2. These 2 numbers (left, right) form a segment, that must be removed from the heap because it's split by the query. But since you can't remove an arbitrary heap element faster than `O(n)`, add the segment boundaries to a set instead.
    3. These 3 numbers (left, query, right) form 2 sub-segments. Find their sums using the prefix sum array (takes `O(1)`). Put the sums into the heap together with their segment boundaries.
    4. Put the query into the BST
    5. Get biggest element in the heap. If it's in the set (of removed segments), pop it from the queue. Keep popping until a not removed segment is found. Put that sum to the result array (don't remove it from the heap).

The problem is that in test cases where the remove queries array is just `[0, 1, 2, 3, ...]`, the BST is very inefficient, even if you balance it times to times. A more tricky BST that joins consecutive numbers can be made, but it's a dead end because there is a much easier and more performant way to solve the problem.

title: Minimum Hours of Training to Win a Competition
question_content:
You are entering a competition, and are given two positive integers initialEnergy and initialExperience denoting your initial energy and initial experience respectively.

You are also given two 0-indexed integer arrays energy and experience, both of length n.

You will face n opponents in order. The energy and experience of the ith opponent is denoted by energy[i] and experience[i] respectively. When you face an opponent, you need to have both strictly greater experience and energy to defeat them and move to the next opponent if available.

Defeating the ith opponent increases your experience by experience[i], but decreases your energy by energy[i].

Before starting the competition, you can train for some number of hours. After each hour of training, you can either choose to increase your initial experience by one, or increase your initial energy by one.

Return the minimum number of training hours required to defeat all n opponents.

 

Example 1:

Input: initialEnergy = 5, initialExperience = 3, energy = [1,4,3,2], experience = [2,6,3,1]
Output: 8
Explanation: You can increase your energy to 11 after 6 hours of training, and your experience to 5 after 2 hours of training.
You face the opponents in the following order:
- You have more energy and experience than the 0th opponent so you win.
  Your energy becomes 11 - 1 = 10, and your experience becomes 5 + 2 = 7.
- You have more energy and experience than the 1st opponent so you win.
  Your energy becomes 10 - 4 = 6, and your experience becomes 7 + 6 = 13.
- You have more energy and experience than the 2nd opponent so you win.
  Your energy becomes 6 - 3 = 3, and your experience becomes 13 + 3 = 16.
- You have more energy and experience than the 3rd opponent so you win.
  Your energy becomes 3 - 2 = 1, and your experience becomes 16 + 1 = 17.
You did a total of 6 + 2 = 8 hours of training before the competition, so we return 8.
It can be proven that no smaller answer exists.

Example 2:

Input: initialEnergy = 2, initialExperience = 4, energy = [1], experience = [3]
Output: 0
Explanation: You do not need any additional energy or experience to win the competition, so we return 0.

 

Constraints:

  • n == energy.length == experience.length
  • 1 <= n <= 100
  • 1 <= initialEnergy, initialExperience, energy[i], experience[i] <= 100

solutions.content:
Explained the variable names in code with comment.
<hr />

The idea is to just greedily simulate the process.

Whenever we don't have enough energy to move to the next stage, we add the minimum required to have +1 energy, and the same for experience.

Then we add the experience from the current stage, and reduce the enery from the current stage as required by the problem.

At the end, we added X energy, and Y experience. So we return the sum, minus the initial starting values we had. 
```
class Solution:
    def minNumberOfHours(self, initialEnergy: int, initialExperience: int, energy: List[int], experience: List[int]) -> int:
        en = 0 # Energy
        ex = 0 # Experience
        
        an = 0 # Added energy
        ax = 0 # Added experience
       
        for ener, exp in zip(energy, experience):
            if ener >= en:
                an += (ener - en + 1)
                en += (ener - en + 1)
            if exp >= ex:
                ax += (exp - ex + 1)
                ex += (exp - ex + 1)
            
            en -= ener
            ex += exp
            
        return max(0, (an - initialEnergy)) + max(0, (ax - initialExperience))
```

	- get sum of opponent energy and calculate hours needed to have at least one more energy

```
class Solution:
    def minNumberOfHours(self, initialEnergy: int, initialExperience: int, energy: List[int], experience: List[int]) -> int:
        hours = 0
        totalEnergy = sum(energy)
        if initialEnergy <= totalEnergy:
            hours += (totalEnergy - initialEnergy + 1)
        for opponentExperience in experience:
            if initialExperience <= opponentExperience:
                hours += (opponentExperience - initialExperience + 1)
                initialExperience = opponentExperience + 1
            initialExperience += opponentExperience
            
        return hours
```

**Intuition**
Here, we can simply run a simulation to progressively check each energy and experience. If the current energy or experience value is not enough to win. Adjust the value and update the answer. 

**Analysis**
Time complexity O(N)
Space complexity O(1) 
```
class Solution: 
    def minNumberOfHours(self, initialEnergy: int, initialExperience: int, energy: List[int], experience: List[int]) -> int:
        ans = 0 
        for x, y in zip(energy, experience): 
            if initialEnergy <= x: 
                ans += x + 1 - initialEnergy
                initialEnergy = x + 1
            if initialExperience <= y: 
                ans += y + 1 - initialExperience
                initialExperience = y + 1
            initialEnergy -= x
            initialExperience += y 
        return ans 
```

2- Video Explanation: [Click Here](https://youtu.be/JaE7uegBikY;)

3- Analysis

"""
Method: linear traversal

Idea:

- During the linear traversal, we check the cur_energy and cur_experience
with the opponent_energy, opponent_experience

- If the cur_engery > opponent_energy and cur_experience > oppenent_experience,
no training is needed.
- Else:
  the training hours needed are:
       if cur_energy < opponent_enery:  
          opponent_energy + 1 - cur_energy
          We can reset the cur_energy = opponent_energy + 1 after traning
       if cur_experience < opponent_experience:
          opponent_experience + 1 - cur_experience
          We can reset the cur_experience = opponent_experience + 1 after traning

  As we have done the reset, after beating current opponent, the energy and experience
  before meeting next opponent are:
        cur_energy - current opponent_energy
        cur_experience + current opponent_experience.
        
        
Walkthrough

initialEnergy = 5, initialExperience = 3, energy = [1,4,3,2], experience = [2,6,3,1]

After beat opponent 0: cur_energy 4, cur_epe 5, res: 0

```python
class Solution:
    def minNumberOfHours(self, initialEnergy: int, initialExperience: int, energy: List[int], experience: List[int]) -> int:
        """
        This function calculates the minimum number of training hours required for 
        the outcome. The function first initialises the required_energy at 0, after 
        which the energy requirement is calculated, relative to initialEnergy. The
        player must end with positive energy, hence the +1. After this, the
        experience component is handled, by evaluating and modifying the
        initialExperience inplace, based on the experience values required. If
        the player cannot win, the required_experience is added as the experience
        required minus the initialExperience, the initialExperience is then modified 
        inplace to reflect this requirement.
        
        :param initialEnergy: the energy of the player. (int)
        :param initialExperience: the experience of the player. (int)
        :param energy: the energy profiles of the other players. (List[int])
        :param experience: the experience profiles of the other players. (List[int])
        :return: the required training time. (int)
        """
        required_experience = 0
        if sum(energy) >= initialEnergy:
            required_energy = sum(energy) - initialEnergy + 1
        else:
            required_energy = 0
            
        for i in range(len(experience)):
            if initialExperience > experience[i]:
                initialExperience += experience[i]
            else:
                required_experience += (experience[i] - initialExperience + 1)
                initialExperience += (experience[i] - initialExperience + 1) + experience[i]
        return (required_energy + required_experience)

solutions.content:
# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
1. Initialize variables exdif to track the difference between current experience and the opponent's experience, and ensum to track the sum of energy.
2. Iterate through the opponents' attributes using a zip of energy and experience lists.
    - If your initial experience is less than or equal to the opponent's experience, update exdif to ensure that you have a positive difference for the required training.
    - Update your experience by adding the opponent's experience and the energy sum by adding the opponent's energy.
3. Calculate the result by finding the maximum between the difference of total energy and initial energy (plus one to represent the time spent training) and exdif. If the calculated result is negative, replace it with zero.
4. Return the calculated result.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: **O(n)**

The time complexity of the solution is **O(n)**, where n is the length of the energy and experience lists. The loop iterates through the lists once to calculate the required values.
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: **O(1)**

The space complexity of this solution is **O(1)**, as it only uses a constant amount of additional space to store the variables (exdif and ensum) regardless of the size of the input lists.
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def minNumberOfHours(self, initialEnergy: int, initialExperience: int, energy: List[int], experience: List[int]) -> int:
        exdif = 0
        ensum = 0
        
        for e, exp in zip(energy, experience):
            if initialExperience <= exp:
                exdif = max(exdif, exp + 1 - initialExperience)
            
            initialExperience += exp
            ensum += e
        
        return max(ensum - initialEnergy + 1, 0) + exdif
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
We can figure out energy ahead of time, but we figure out expeirence by going into fights and adjusting as needed.

# Approach
1. Find the sum of energy and compare with initial energy.  If initial energy is bigger, we don't have to train for more energy at all.  Otherwise, we need to train enough to make them equal, plus 1.
2. Go through the opponents and compare experience:
    - If your experience is higher, add their experience without changing total.
    - If you experience is *lower*, add the difference (subtract the negative difference) from count, and subtract 1 more.  You need to train enough to be one more, plus you'll add their experience, so you final experience will be double theirs + 1.
3. Return count.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
$$O(n)$$

- Space complexity:
$$O(1)$$

# Code
```
def min_number_of_hours(initial_energy, initial_experience, energy, experience)
    count = initial_energy > energy.sum ? 0 : energy.sum + 1 - initial_energy

    (0...experience.length).each do |i|
        diff = initial_experience - experience[i]
        if diff > 0
            initial_experience += experience[i]
        else
            count -= diff - 1
            initial_experience = 2 * experience[i] + 1
        end
    end

    count
end
```

var minNumberOfHours = function(initialEnergy, initialExperience, energy, experience) {
    let eng = initialEnergy
    let exp = initialExperience
    let rest = 0

  	for (let round = 0; round < energy.length; round++) {
        let enemyExp = experience[round]
        let enemyEng = energy[round]
      
        if (enemyExp >= exp && rest <= enemyExp - exp) {
      	    rest = (enemyExp - exp) + 1
        }
      
        exp += enemyExp
        eng -= enemyEng
    }
    
    if (eng <= 0) {
    	rest += Math.abs(eng) + 1
    }

    return rest
};

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
Training hours for **Energy** can be calculated in just one line.
Training hours for **Experience** are a bit more complicated, the most evident way is to traverse them one by one.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
- **Energy** : All we need is an additional amount of energy which is slightly greater than the sum of all opponents' energy. If our initial energy is significantly high, we don't have to train at all.

        energy_hr = sum(energy) - initialEnergy + 1

-   **Experience** : For each iteration, there are two values that need updating. First, the amount of training hours needed (**ex_hr**) for every single opponent. Second is our current experience (**initialExperience**), since we receive an extra amount of experience whenever we win.

        if initialExperience <= experience[i]:
            s = (experience[i] - initialExperience) + 1
            ex_hr += s
            initialExperience += s + experience[i]
        else: initialExperience+=experience[i]

# Complexity
- Time complexity:  $$O(n)$$
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: $$O(1)$$
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def minNumberOfHours(self, initialEnergy: int, initialExperience: int, energy: list[int], experience: list[int]) -> int:
        energy_hr = sum(energy) - initialEnergy + 1
        ex_hr,s = 0,0
        if energy_hr < 0:
            energy_hr = 0

        if len(energy) == 1:
            if experience[0] < initialExperience:  
                ex_hr = 0
            else: ex_hr = experience[0] - initialExperience + 1
            return energy_hr + ex_hr

        for i in range(len(experience)):
            if initialExperience <= experience[i]:
                s = (experience[i] - initialExperience) + 1
                ex_hr += s
                initialExperience += s + experience[i]
            else: initialExperience+=experience[i]


        return energy_hr + ex_hr
```

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
Note that it is said in the question that energy and experience should be strictly greater while defeating someone. Hence, 1 more level should be added to whenever our initial energy and experience level becomes equal to defeating someone. Reminder that energy decreases after defeating and experience increases.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(n)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: O(1)

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def minNumberOfHours(self, initialEnergy: int, initialExperience: int, energy: List[int], experience: List[int]) -> int:
        n=len(energy)

        needed=0
        current_energy=initialEnergy
        current_experience=initialExperience

        for i in range(n):
            if current_energy<=energy[i]:
                delta=energy[i]-current_energy+1
                needed+=delta
                current_energy+=delta
            if current_experience<=experience[i]:
                delta=experience[i]-current_experience+1
                needed+=delta
                current_experience+=delta
            current_energy-=energy[i]
            current_experience+=experience[i]
        return needed
        
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

Iterate through the energy and experience arrays.
If your `initialEnergy` is not enough, add the difference plus one to the result and your `initialEnergy` becomes 1.
If your `initialExperience` is not enough, add the difference plus one to the result and your `initialExperience` becomes `2*experience+1`.


# Complexity
- Time complexity: `O(n)`
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: `O(1)`
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def minNumberOfHours(self, initialEnergy: int, initialExperience: int, energy: List[int], experience: List[int]) -> int:

        res = [0, 0]
        for en, ex in zip(energy, experience):
            if initialEnergy <= en:
                res[0] += (en - initialEnergy) + 1
                initialEnergy = 1
            else:
                initialEnergy -= en

            if initialExperience <= ex:
                res[1] += (ex - initialExperience) + 1
                initialExperience = ex * 2 + 1
            else:
                initialExperience += ex
        return sum(res)
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
It's quite easy to see that the total energy required is one plus the sum of the energy array, and to find the total experience, we need only to find the maximum of the experience minus the accumulated experience beforehand and add one.
# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
A simple one time loop is sufficient to find both of our required values.
# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
$$O(n)$$
- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
$$O(1)$$
# Code
```
class Solution:
    def minNumberOfHours(self, initialEnergy: int, initialExperience: int, energy: List[int], experience: List[int]) -> int:
        expn = initialExperience
        total = 0
        for exp in experience:
            if exp + 1 - total > expn:
                expn = exp + 1 - total
            total += exp
        energyn = sum(energy) + 1 - initialEnergy if sum(energy) + 1 > initialEnergy else 0
        return energyn + expn - initialExperience
```

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
Tried to keep it as simple as possible. By far not the best solution but I think its not too difficult to follow.


# Code
```
class Solution(object):
    def minNumberOfHours(self, initialEnergy, initialExperience, energy, experience):
        """
        :type initialEnergy: int
        :type initialExperience: int
        :type energy: List[int]
        :type experience: List[int]
        :rtype: int
        """
        # Number of hours needed for Training
        hrs_train = 0
        # Total Opposition Energy
        opp_energy = 0

        # Calculating Total Opposition Energy
        for i in energy:
            opp_energy += i

        #print("Opponent Energy",opp_energy)

        # Adds hours to training whether initial Energy is 1 or greater
        if opp_energy - initialEnergy >= 0:
            if initialEnergy == 1:
                hrs_train = opp_energy 
            else:    
                hrs_train = (opp_energy - initialEnergy) + 1

        #print("Hours Energy Training Needed", hrs_train)
        
        # For Total Experience Gained
        exp = initialExperience
        # Hours Difference for needed Experience
        diff = 0 

        # Loop through experience and calculating number of necessarry training hours
        for i in range(len(experience)):
            # Finding difference between each experience value and dealing with it accordingly
            if exp < experience[i]:
                diff = experience[i] - exp + 1
                hrs_train = hrs_train + diff

            # If experience is the same only an extra hour/ experience point is needed
            if exp == experience[i]:
                diff = 1
                hrs_train = hrs_train + 1

            # Experience is calculated each turn to update new experience gained and appropriate difference if any
            exp = exp + experience[i] + diff
            diff = 0

        return hrs_train
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
1. Since we know an hour of work before either gets us one more energy or experience, it is fairly straightforward to make 1 pass through the array, compute the number of hours of work we need to do to get the minimum required energy, compute the number of hours of work we need to do to get the minimum required experience, and add them together.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
We do one loop through the energy and experience array. since their length is the same, we do all the computation within a single loop. 
Two cases. How to deal with energy? How to deal with effort?
1. Initialize two variables, initialEnergy and initialExperience, and set them equal to the parameters in the problem
2. for each value in the energy array, we are going to test our initialenergy against it. if initialenergy is greater than it, great, no need to do any work before we fight all n bad guys. just update initialenergy, so it is now equal to initialenergy - energy[i] where i is the currentindex. If energy[i] is greater than or equal to initial energy, we need to add the number of hours to get initialenergy 1 above energy[i] to the counter (ret), and run simulation accordingly.
Use similar logic for experience, but remember experience is added, not subtracted.
3. add the computations together

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
O(n)

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
O(1)

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def minNumberOfHours(self, initialEnergy: int, initialExperience: int, energy: List[int], experience: List[int]) -> int:
        ret = 0
        for i in range(0, len(energy)):
            if energy[i] >= initialEnergy:
                ret += energy[i] - initialEnergy + 1
                initialEnergy = 1
            else:
                initialEnergy -= energy[i]
            if experience[i] >= initialExperience:
                ret += experience[i] - initialExperience + 1
                initialExperience = experience[i] + 1 + experience[i]

            else:
                initialExperience += experience[i]
        return ret

title: Largest Palindromic Number
question_content:
You are given a string num consisting of digits only.

Return the largest palindromic integer (in the form of a string) that can be formed using digits taken from num. It should not contain leading zeroes.

Notes:

  • You do not need to use all the digits of num, but you must use at least one digit.
  • The digits can be reordered.

 

Example 1:

Input: num = "444947137"
Output: "7449447"
Explanation: 
Use the digits "4449477" from "444947137" to form the palindromic integer "7449447".
It can be shown that "7449447" is the largest palindromic integer that can be formed.

Example 2:

Input: num = "00009"
Output: "9"
Explanation: 
It can be shown that "9" is the largest palindromic integer that can be formed.
Note that the integer returned should not contain leading zeroes.

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= num.length <= 105
  • num consists of digits.

solutions.title: python-hashmap-solution-with-explanation
solutions.content:
# **Explanation** 1. Count the frequency of all digits in `num` 2. Check how many pair of `9` that we have: If we have one pair of `9`, we can make `9XXXXXX9`, `res = '99'` now. If we have two pairs of `9`, we can make `99XXXX99`, `res = '9'` now. 3. Continue check pairs for 8,7,6,5,4,3,2,1,0 4. Strip the leading `0` in `res` 5. Find the maximum digit left that can be used for the middle digit of palindromic number. 6. final result is `res + mid + reversed(res)` 7. For special input like `00`, we need to return `0`.
# **Complexity** Time `O(n)` Space `O(n)`
**Python** ```py def largestPalindromic(self, num: str) -> str: count = Counter(num) res = ''.join(count[i] // 2 * i for i in '9876543210').lstrip('0') mid = max(count[i] % 2 * i for i in count) return (res + mid + res[::-1]) or '0' ```
solutions.code:
```py
    def largestPalindromic(self, num: str) -> str:
        count = Counter(num)
        res = ''.join(count[i] // 2 * i for i in '9876543210').lstrip('0')
        mid = max(count[i] % 2 * i for i in count)
        return (res + mid + res[::-1]) or '0'
```

solutions.content:
when you append char to your string(ans) try to append like this..
**ans += s[i];**   (here s is the given string).
If you append char like ans = ans + s[i];  it will give you Memory Limit Exceeded.

Reason->>>>>>>>

string operator+(string&, string&) operator copies the arguments into a new string object. You then copy this temporary return value into res - which may also involve copying into a new, larger buffer. Unless C++11 is enabled, in which case move assignment will be used, so the latter potential allocation + copy is avoided.

string& operator+=(const string&) does not create a new string object. It modifies the existing string buffer in-place - unless a larger buffer is needed, in which case reallocation cannot be avoided.

**So, res += c avoids creation of temporary buffers in dynamic memory. If the string is large enough, doubling the number of simultaneously used copies can roughly double the peak memory use of the program. Also, the extra temporary allocations may increase the fragmentation of dynamic memory space, which increases the overhead of dynamic memory management. These two factors may cause the memory limit given for the program to be exceeded.**

def largestPalindromic(self, num: str) -> str:
		count = Counter(num)
		palindrome = mid = ''

		for d in sorted(count.keys(), reverse=True):
			mid = max(mid, d * (count[d] & 1))
			palindrome += d * (count[d] // 2)

		palindrome = palindrome.lstrip('0')
		return (palindrome + mid + palindrome[::-1]) or '0'

solutions.content:
# Intuition
- In a palindrome, every character except the middle character occurs an even number of times, e.g. '12321'. Here '1' and '2' occur 2 times each.
- The middle character either does not exist (in the case of a palindrome of even length), e.g. '1221', or occurs an odd number of times, e.g. '1233321', where the middle character '3' occurs 3 times.
- If the occurrences of each character are counted, the counts of each character can be used to create a palindrome.
- As the largest palindrome is to be returned, the digits with the largest value should occur earliest in the palindrome.

# Approach
- Create a dictionary 'counts' to store the number of occurrences of each digit in the input string.
- Initialize two arrays 'front' and 'back'. 'front' will contain the characters in first half of the palindrome (including the middle character), while 'back' will contain the characters in the second half of the palindrome.
- Iterate through digits [9-0] in descending order (so the palindrome will be of the largest value). If the digit is in 'counts', add the digit to both the two arrays till its total number of occurrences in the front and back is equal to the highest even number less than the count.
- If 'front' is empty, do not add '0' to 'front' or 'back'. These will be leading zeros in the palindrome, which are to be avoided.
- Find the largest digit with an odd number of occurrences in count (if any). If there is, add this digit to 'front'. This will be the the middle character of the palindrome.
- Reverse 'back' and combine it with 'front'. Convert the combined array to a string and return it.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(n)$$, the operations of creating the dictionary, adding digits to the arrays, and converting to string are all $$O(n)$$.
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: $$O(n)$$, the arrays created are of $$O(n)$$ space complexity.
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def largestPalindromic(self, num: str) -> str:

        #Process input
        counts = collections.Counter(num)

        #Initialize two arrays
        front = []
        back = []

        #Handle case of Zeros
        if len(counts) == 1 and counts['0']>=1:
            return '0'

        #Add digits [1-9] to front and back arrays
        temp = middle = None
        for digit in range(9,0,-1):
            temp = counts[str(digit)]
            while temp - 2 >= 0:
                front.append(str(digit))
                back.append(str(digit))
                temp -= 2
            if temp > 0 and not middle:
                middle = str(digit)

        #Add digit 0 to front and back arrays
        #Handle case of leading zeros
        if front and counts['0']:
            temp = counts['0']
            while temp - 2 >= 0:
                front.append('0')
                back.append('0')
                temp -= 2
            if temp > 0 and not middle:
                middle = '0'

        #Add middle digit to front array
        if middle:
            front.append(middle)

        #Join arrays, convert to string and return
        return "".join(front+list(reversed(back)))
        
        
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def largestPalindromic(self, num: str) -> str:
        from collections import defaultdict

        # Step 1: Create a dictionary to count the occurrences of each digit.
        digit_count = defaultdict(int)
        for x in num:
            digit_count[x] += 1

        # Step 2: Create a list of digits in decreasing order (from 9 to 0).
        digits = [str(x) for x in range(9, -1, -1)]

        # Step 3: Initialize a list to build the largest palindromic integer.
        palindrome = []

        # Step 4: Iterate through the digits in decreasing order.
        for digit in digits:
            count = digit_count[digit]
            n = len(palindrome)

            if n % 2 == 0:
                # If the current palindrome length is even:
                if count > 0:
                    # Add the digit to both sides of the palindrome.
                    palindrome = palindrome[:n // 2] + [digit] * count + palindrome[n // 2:]
            else:
                # If the current palindrome length is odd:
                if digit == '0':
                    if len(palindrome) != 1:
                        # If there is more than one digit in the palindrome, add '0' in the middle.
                        palindrome = palindrome[:n // 2] + ['0'] * (count // 2) + [palindrome[n // 2]] + ['0'] * (count // 2) + palindrome[n // 2 + 1:]
                else:
                    # Add the digit to both sides of the palindrome.
                    if count >= 2:
                        palindrome = palindrome[:n // 2] + [digit] * (count // 2) + [palindrome[n // 2]] + [digit] * (count // 2) + palindrome[n // 2 + 1:]

        # Step 5: Convert the list to a string and remove leading zeroes.
        result = ''.join(palindrome).lstrip('0')

        # Step 6: Return the largest palindromic integer as a string.
        return result if result else '0'



        

```

solutions.content:
# Approach
Build the first half of the palindrome from the largest numbers first 
If there are zeros and the first half is not empty then add them
The middle will be the largest odd number unless there are no odd numbers then we use zero
Join the first half, middle and first half reversed

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(n)$$
- Space complexity: $$O(n)$$

# Code
```
# @param {String} num
# @return {String}
def largest_palindromic(num)
  h = num.chars.tally
  pairs = h.map { |k, v| [k.to_i, v] }.sort_by { |k| -k[0] }

  middle = nil
  ans = ""

  # Add the first half of the palindrome in order
  pairs.each do |c, v|
    ans << c.to_s * (v / 2)  if v > 1 && c > 0
  end

  # if the ans is not empty and the zero count is > 1 the add them 
  ans << '0' * (h['0'] / 2) if !ans.empty? && h['0'] && h['0'] > 1

  # find the middle
  pairs.each do |c, v|
    if v.odd?
      middle = c.to_s
      break
    end
  end

  #  if the middle not found and the ans is empty middle is zero
  middle = '0' if middle.nil? && ans.empty?
  [ans, middle, ans.reverse].join
end
```

solutions.content:
# Approach
Largest palindromic number comprises decreasing outer to inner shell and a largest seen center, but 0 could not be the outermost shell.

If the number doesn't have a shell, then it is the biggest digit ever seen. 

# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(N)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: O(10)
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def largestPalindromic(self, num: str) -> str:
        L = [0 for _ in range(10)]
        s = ''

        for c in num:
            L[int(c)] += 1
        
        d = 0 if L[0] % 2 else -1

        for i in range(1, 10):
            s += str(i) * (L[i]//2)
            if L[i] % 2:
                d = i
        
        if len(s) > 0 and d > -1:
            s = '0' * (L[0] // 2) + s 
            s = s[::-1] + str(d) + s
        elif len(s) > 0 and d < 0:
            s = '0' * (L[0] // 2) + s 
            s = s[::-1] + s
        elif len(s) < 1 and d > -1:
            s = s[::-1] + str(d) + s
        else:
            s = '0'
        #print(d)
        return s


```

# Intuition
Count the string and store it in a heap. Doing heappop and add the halpf of the item to a list. Return the list and resverse of the list. Put the largest odd item in the middle if there is any. 

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
$$O(nlogn)$$

- Space complexity:
$$O(n)$$

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def largestPalindromic(self, num: str) -> str:
        s = list(map(int, str(num)))
        sc = collections.Counter(s)

        h = [(-k, -v) for k, v in sc.items()]
        heapq.heapify(h)
        ret = list()
        m = -1

        while h:
            k, v = heapq.heappop(h)
            v = -v
            k = -k

            n = v // 2
            ret.extend([k] * n)
            
            if v % 2 == 1:
                if m < k:
                    m = k

        # print(ret)

        if m == -1:
            res =  ret + list(reversed(ret))
        else:
            res =  ret + [m] + list(reversed(ret))

        res = [str(s) for s in res]

        res = "".join(res).strip("0")
        if not res:
            return "0"

        return res
        
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
Given a string of digits, the goal is to find the largest palindromic number that can be formed using these digits. We need to maximize the palindromic number by placing the largest digits at the beginning and end of the palindrome while ensuring that the result is a valid palindrome.

# Approach
Our approach to solving this problem involves counting the frequency of each digit in the input string and utilizing the digits with the highest frequency to construct the largest palindromic number. We'll start by placing the largest digits at the outer positions of the palindrome and then fill in the center with the largest remaining digit with an odd count, if any.

# Algorithm
1. Count the frequency of each digit in the input string using a Counter.
2. Initialize an empty string front to represent the first half of the palindrome.
3. Iterate through the digits from 9 to 1 (inclusive). For each digit, if its count is greater than or equal to 2, append the digit to front repeated count // 2 times.
4. If front is non-empty and there are at least two 0's in the input, append the required number of 0's to front.
5. Initialize an empty string center to represent the middle character of the palindrome.
6. Iterate through the digits from 9 to 0 (inclusive). If a digit has an odd count, set center to the string representation of that digit and break the loop.
7. Handle the special case when there are only even counts of 0's in the input by setting center to "0" if both front and center are empty.
8. Construct the final palindrome by concatenating front, center, and the reverse of front.

# Corner Cases
1. Input contains only even counts of 0's: The largest palindromic number will be a single 0, as no other digits are available to create a palindrome.
2. Input contains only one digit: The input itself is the largest palindrome.
3. Input contains all odd counts: We use the largest digit with an odd count as the center and then create a palindrome using the remaining digits.



# Complexity
 - Time complexity: $$O(n)$$, where n is the length of the input string. We iterate through the input string once for counting and then through the digits 0 to 9 twice.
 - Space complexity: $$O(n)$$, as we store the count of each digit in the input string and construct the result string.

# Code
```
from collections import Counter

class Solution:
    def largestPalindromic(self, num: str) -> str:
        # Count the frequency of each digit in the input string.
        digit_counts = Counter(num)
        
        # Initialize an empty string for the first half of the palindrome.
        first_half = ""
        
        # Iterate through the digits from 9 to 1 (inclusive).
        # If a digit has an even count, add it to the first half of the palindrome.
        for digit in range(9, 0, -1):
            if digit_counts[str(digit)] >= 2:
                first_half += str(digit) * (digit_counts[str(digit)] // 2)

        # If the first half is non-empty and there are at least two 0's,
        # add the required number of 0's to the first half.
        if first_half and digit_counts['0'] >= 2:
            first_half += '0' * (digit_counts['0'] // 2)
        
        # Initialize an empty string for the middle character of the palindrome.
        middle_char = ""
        
        # Iterate through the digits from 9 to 0 (inclusive).
        # If a digit has an odd count, set the middle character to the digit and break the loop.
        for digit in range(9, -1, -1):
            if digit_counts[str(digit)] % 2 == 1:
                middle_char = str(digit)
                break
        
        # If both the first half and the middle character are empty,
        # set the middle character to "0" as a special case.
        if not first_half and not middle_char:
            middle_char = "0"
        
        # Construct the final palindrome by concatenating the first half,
        # middle character, and the reverse of the first half.
        return first_half + middle_char + first_half[::-1]

```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
- In a palindrome, every character except the middle character occurs an even number of times, e.g. '12321'. Here '1' and '2' occur 2 times each.
- The middle character either does not exist (in the case of a palindrome of even length), e.g. '1221', or occurs an odd number of times, e.g. '1233321', where the middle character '3' occurs 3 times.
- If the occurrences of each character are counted, the counts of each character can be used to create a palindrome.
- As the largest palindrome is to be returned, the digits with the largest value should occur earliest in the palindrome.

# Approach
- Create a dictionary 'counts' to store the number of occurrences of each digit in the input string.
- Initialize two arrays 'front' and 'back'. 'front' will contain the characters of the first half of the palindrome (including the middle character), while 'back' will contain the characters of the second half of the palindrome.
- Iterate through digits [9-0] in descending order (so the palindrome will be of the largest value). If the digit is in 'counts', add the digit to both the two arrays till its total number of occurrences in the front and back is equal to the highest even number less than the count.
- If 'front' is empty, do not add '0' to 'front' or 'back'. These will be leading zeros in the palindrome, which are to be avoided.
- Find the largest digit with an odd number of occurrences in count (if any). If there is, add this digit to 'front'. This will be the middle character of the palindrome.
- Reverse 'back' and combine it with 'front'. Convert the combined array to a string and return it.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(n)$$, the operations of creating the dictionary, adding digits to the arrays, and converting to string are all $$O(n)$$.
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: $$O(n)$$, the arrays created are of $$O(n)$$ space complexity.
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def largestPalindromic(self, num: str) -> str:

        #Process input
        counts = collections.Counter(num)

        #Handle case of Zeros
        if len(counts) == 1 and counts['0']>=1:
            return '0'

        #Initialize two arrays
        front = []
        back = []

        #Add digits [1-9] to front and back arrays
        temp = middle = None
        for digit in map(str,range(9,0,-1)):
            temp = counts[digit]
            while temp - 2 >= 0:
                front.append(digit)
                back.append(digit)
                temp -= 2
            if temp > 0 and not middle:
                middle = digit

        #Add digit 0 to front and back arrays
        #Handle case of leading zeros
        if front and counts['0']:
            temp = counts['0']
            while temp - 2 >= 0:
                front.append('0')
                back.append('0')
                temp -= 2
            if temp > 0 and not middle:
                middle = '0'

        #Add middle digit to front array
        if middle:
            front.append(middle)

        #Join arrays, convert to string and return
        return "".join(front+list(reversed(back)))
        
        
```

essentially ripping off all the "count digit in string" problems in K and R.  Character '0' provides for interesting edge cases.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:

- Space complexity:
O(n) since we're building the result string

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def largestPalindromic(self, num: str) -> str:
        count = [0] * 10

        for char in num:
            count[int(char)] += 1

        even = [0] * 10
        odd = [0] * 10

        for i, c in enumerate(count): #build even and odd occurances in palindrome
            even[i] += c // 2
            odd[i] += c % 2

        outer = ""; mid = "" #some people may not like this but pythons is less intuitive

        for i in range(9, 0, -1): #build the even outside
            outer = outer + str(i) * even[i]
        if len(outer) > 0:
            outer = outer + str(0) * even[0]

        for i in range(9, -1, -1): #build the odd inside, if it exists
            if odd[i]:
                mid = mid + str(i) #creamy creamy nuget
                break

        #pita edge case
        if len(outer) == 0 and len(mid) == 0 and even[0] > 0:
            return "0"

        return outer + mid + outer[::-1]

        
        

        
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition and approach
>for making largest palindromic no. we had to get count of each digit.
>after getting count we will iterate from 9 to 1 and add digit at the end of first string and at the front of third string(initiallay first, second and third strings are empty)
>if we get any odd frequency digit then we will ad a digit in to second string. 
>at the end we will join first +second +third  and return final string.

** digit in second string can be added at once only.
** if digit is zero and first string is empty then do not add zero to it
** if final string is empty and freq of zero is not zero then return "0" 


# Complexity
- Time complexity:o(n)

- Space complexity:o(n)

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def largestPalindromic(self, num: str) -> str:
        a=[0 for i in range(10)]
        for i in range(len(num)):
            a[int(num[i])]+=1
        f=1
        str1=""
        str2=""
        str3=""
        for i in range(9,-1,-1):
            if(i==0 and len(str1)==0):
                continue
            while(a[i]>1):
                str1+=str(i)
                str3=str(i)+str3
                a[i]-=2
            if(f and a[i]==1):
                str2=str(i)
                f=0

        s=str1+str2+str3
        if(len(s)==0 and a[0]>0):
            return "0"
        return s
```

title: Amount of Time for Binary Tree to Be Infected
question_content:
You are given the root of a binary tree with unique values, and an integer start. At minute 0, an infection starts from the node with value start.

Each minute, a node becomes infected if:

  • The node is currently uninfected.
  • The node is adjacent to an infected node.

Return the number of minutes needed for the entire tree to be infected.

 

Example 1:

Input: root = [1,5,3,null,4,10,6,9,2], start = 3
Output: 4
Explanation: The following nodes are infected during:
- Minute 0: Node 3
- Minute 1: Nodes 1, 10 and 6
- Minute 2: Node 5
- Minute 3: Node 4
- Minute 4: Nodes 9 and 2
It takes 4 minutes for the whole tree to be infected so we return 4.

Example 2:

Input: root = [1], start = 1
Output: 0
Explanation: At minute 0, the only node in the tree is infected so we return 0.

 

Constraints:

  • The number of nodes in the tree is in the range [1, 105].
  • 1 <= Node.val <= 105
  • Each node has a unique value.
  • A node with a value of start exists in the tree.

solutions.content:
This is a classic BFS problem.

In order to travel the tree upwards, let's create a graph from it using DFS.

```
class Solution:
    def amountOfTime(self, root: Optional[TreeNode], start: int) -> int:
        graph = defaultdict(list)
        
        def build_graph(parent, node):
            if not node: return 
            
            if parent:
                graph[parent.val].append(node)
                graph[node.val].append(parent)
            
            build_graph(node, node.left)
            build_graph(node, node.right)
        
        build_graph(None, root)
        
        vis = set()
        max_infection = 0
        queue = deque([(start, 0)])
        vis.add(start)
        
        while queue:
            node_val, time = queue.popleft()
            max_infection = max(max_infection, time)
            
            for nei in graph[node_val]:
                if nei.val not in vis:
                    vis.add(nei.val)
                    queue.append((nei.val, time + 1))
        
        return max_infection
```

solutions.content:
First use the same pattern as [863. All Nodes Distance K in Binary Tree](https://leetcode.com/problems/all-nodes-distance-k-in-binary-tree/) to build an undirected graph.

Then use the neighbor-order traversal to traverse all nodes by levels just as  [994. Rotting Oranges](https://leetcode.com/problems/rotting-oranges/).

```
# Definition for a binary tree node.
# class TreeNode:
#     def __init__(self, val=0, left=None, right=None):
#         self.val = val
#         self.left = left
#         self.right = right
class Solution:
    def amountOfTime(self, root: Optional[TreeNode], start: int) -> int:
        """
        graph: {1: [5,3], 5: [1,4], 3: [1,6,10], ...}
        """
        graph = defaultdict(list)
        def dfs(parent, node):
            if not parent or not node:
                return
            graph[parent.val].append(node.val)
            graph[node.val].append(parent.val)
            if node.left:
                dfs(node, node.left)
            if node.right:
                dfs(node, node.right)
        dfs(root, root.left) 
        dfs(root, root.right)
        
        q = deque([start])
        v = set([start])
        step = 0
        while q:
            sz = len(q)
            for _ in range(sz):
                node = q.popleft()
                for nei in graph[node]:
                    if nei not in v:
                        v.add(nei)
                        q.append(nei)
            step += 1
        return step-1
```

Time: `O(Depth of Tree)`
Space: `O(V+E) = O(N)`

    def amountOfTime(self, root, start):
        """
        :type root: Optional[TreeNode]
        :type start: int
        :rtype: int
        """
        self.startNode = None
        parent = {}
        def helper(root):
            if not root:
                return
            if root.val == start:
                self.startNode = root
            if root.left:
                parent[root.left] = root
                helper(root.left)
            if root.right:
                parent[root.right] = root
                helper(root.right)
        helper(root)

        q = collections.deque()
        q.append(self.startNode)
        dis = -1
        seen = set()
        seen.add(self.startNode.val)
        while q:
            size = len(q)
            for i in range(size):
                cur = q.popleft()
                if cur.left and (cur.left.val not in seen):
                    seen.add(cur.left.val)
                    q.append(cur.left)
                if cur.right and (cur.right.val not in seen):
                    seen.add(cur.right.val)
                    q.append(cur.right)
                if cur in parent and (parent[cur].val not in seen):
                    seen.add(parent[cur].val)
                    q.append(parent[cur])
            dis += 1
        return dis

solutions.content:
# Intuition
since we have to traverse back in the tree[top and bottom traversal]
We use Hashing. 
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
We can make use of a hashmap where we make the children and parent mapping.
Use BFS for traversing the node. Insert the currently visited node to visited set increment the time by 1 each time you visit a node.Do this recursively till the queue is empty
at last return the time.
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(n)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:O(n)
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
# Definition for a binary tree node.
# class TreeNode:
#     def __init__(self, val=0, left=None, right=None):
#         self.val = val
#         self.left = left
#         self.right = right
class Solution:
    def amountOfTime(self, root: Optional[TreeNode], start: int) -> int:
        dict_ = defaultdict(list)
        def buildgraph(cur,parent):
            if cur and parent:
                dict_[cur.val].append(parent.val)
                dict_[parent.val].append(cur.val)
            if cur.left:
                buildgraph(cur.left,cur)
            if cur.right:
                buildgraph(cur.right,cur)
        buildgraph(root,0)
        
        infected = set()
        queue = [(start,0)]
        while queue:
            node,t=queue.pop(0)
            infected.add(node)
            for nei in dict_[node]:
                if nei not in infected:
                    queue.append((nei,t+1))
                    
        return t



```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
Find the longest path from the start node
# Complexity
- Time complexity:
$$O(n)$$
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
$$O(log(n))$$
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
# Definition for a binary tree node.
# class TreeNode:
#     def __init__(self, val=0, left=None, right=None):
#         self.val = val
#         self.left = left
#         self.right = right
class Solution:
    def amountOfTime(self, root: Optional[TreeNode], start: int) -> int:
        # find the longest path from the start
        def findMaxDepth(root):
            #
            if not root:
                return 0,0,0,0
            #l:    max depth,
            #spl:  start to node length
            #sel:  longest path from start to end
            #rl:   return result
            
            l,spl,sel,rl=findMaxDepth(root.left)
            r,spr,ser,rr=findMaxDepth(root.right)
            depth=max(l,r)+1
            if root.val==start:
                return depth,1,depth,depth-1
            else:
                if spl!=0:
                    return depth,spl+1,sel,max(rl,sel-1,spl+r)
                elif spr!=0:
                    return depth,spr+1,ser,max(rr,ser-1,spr+l)
                else:
                    return depth,0,0,0
                    
            
        return findMaxDepth(root)[3]
```

solutions.content:
Let's take some node for example. Only two scenarios are possible:
* Neither left nor right subtree contains the infected node.
* One of the left and right subtrees contains the infected node.

The idea is to return two values:
- `distance` : The distance from the current node to the infected node, if the current node is a parent of it (doesn't have to be direct parent), or -1 if it isn't.
- `infect_time` : The time that it will take to infect the subtree that is rooted in the current node.

The first value is easy to keep track of - We return -1 until we found the infected node, at which point we will return 0. then, we check at each node if  `distance != -1` for left or right, and add 1 to it.

The second value if a little more complex:
- If we did not find the infected node yet, we return the depth of the current subtree.
- If we found it, then the time it'll take is the maximum of the following:
	- either it takes as much time as it takes to infect the subtree that contains the infected node.
	- or, the distance from the infected node to the left\right child nodes, +1 to get to the current node, +1 to get to the other subtree (left\right), and the depth of that subtree.

```
class Solution:
    def amountOfTime(self, root, start: int) -> int:
        time_to_infect_tree, _ = self.dfs(root, start)
        return time_to_infect_tree

    def dfs(self, root, start):
        if root == None:
            return -1, -1

        left_infect_time, left_distance = self.dfs(root.left, start)
        right_infect_time, right_distance = self.dfs(root.right, start)
		
        if left_distance == -1 and right_distance == -1:
            distance = -1
            infect_time = max(right_infect_time, left_infect_time) + 1

        elif left_distance != -1:
            distance = left_distance + 1
            infect_time = max(left_infect_time, right_infect_time + left_distance + 2)
           
        else:
            distance = right_distance + 1
            infect_time = max(right_infect_time, left_infect_time + right_distance + 2)

        if root.val == start:
            distance = 0

        return infect_time, distance
```

With Extra Comments:
```
class Solution:
    def amountOfTime(self, root, start: int) -> int:
        time_to_infect_tree, _ = self.dfs(root, start)
        return time_to_infect_tree

    def dfs(self, root, start):

        # if root is None
        if root == None:
            return -1, -1

        # get time to infect subtree from root, as well as distance from root of subtree
        # to the infected node (-1 if root is not a parent of it)
        left_infect_time, left_distance = self.dfs(root.left, start)
        right_infect_time, right_distance = self.dfs(root.right, start)

        # if both subtrees don't contain the infected node
        if left_distance == -1 and right_distance == -1:
            distance = -1
            # infect time is as if from root node, AKA simply the depth of the subtree
            infect_time = max(right_infect_time, left_infect_time) + 1

        # if left subtree contains the infected node
        elif left_distance != -1:
            # update distance to infected node
            distance = left_distance + 1
            # distance to the infected node from root.left, then two edges to root.right (+2), then
            # infect time of right subtree as if from root.right
            infect_time = max(left_infect_time, right_infect_time + left_distance + 2)
            
        # same as before, but with right subtree containing the infected
        else:
            distance = right_distance + 1
            infect_time = max(right_infect_time, left_infect_time + right_distance + 2)

        # if found the infected node
        if root.val == start:
            distance = 0

        return infect_time, distance
```

        right_infect_time, right_distance = self.dfs(root.right, start)

        # if both subtrees don't contain the infected node
        if left_distance == -1 and right_distance == -1:
            distance = -1
            # infect time is as if from root node, AKA simply the depth of the subtree
            infect_time = max(right_infect_time, left_infect_time) + 1

        # if left subtree contains the infected node
        elif left_distance != -1:
            # update distance to infected node
            distance = left_distance + 1
            # distance to the infected node from root.left, then two edges to root.right (+2), then
            # infect time of right subtree as if from root.right
            infect_time = max(left_infect_time, right_infect_time + left_distance + 2)
            
        # same as before, but with right subtree containing the infected
        else:
            distance = right_distance + 1
            infect_time = max(right_infect_time, left_infect_time + right_distance + 2)

        # if found the infected node
        if root.val == start:
            distance = 0

        return infect_time, distance
```

solutions.content:
Idea is that we can mutate the given tree node to hold parent pointers.
1. Add parent pointer to all the nodes
2. Calculate max depth from the start node
```
def amountOfTime(self, root: Optional[TreeNode], start: int) -> int:
	# DFS function to add parent pointer to all nodes and get the start node
	def addParent(node, parent):
		if not node:
			return

		node.parent = parent # mutating node and adding parent pointer
		if node.val == start: # get the start node
			nonlocal startNode 
			startNode = node

		addParent(node.left, node)
		addParent(node.right, node)
	
	# DFS function to calculate root to leaf maximum depth, here root is start node
	def maxDepth(node):
		if not node or node in seen:
			return 0

		seen.add(node)

		return 1 + max(maxDepth(node.left), maxDepth(node.right), maxDepth(node.parent))

	seen = set()
	startNode = None
	addParent(root, None)

	return maxDepth(startNode) - 1 # -1 to exclude the startNode
```

Time: `O(n)` 
Space: `O(n)`

solutions.content:
This question is very similar to [863. All Nodes Distance K in Binary Tree](https://leetcode.com/problems/all-nodes-distance-k-in-binary-tree/)
in a sense that we could add a "parent" variable to each tree node and use it to find the distance to the furthest node from the start node.

Three steps: 
1. Assign parent node to each node in the tree
2. Identify the start node
3. calculate the distance from start node to the furthest node

Time O(n); Space O(n)
```
class Solution:
    def amountOfTime(self, root: Optional[TreeNode], start: int) -> int:
		self.startNode = None
		
        def addParent(root, parent) -> None: 
            if not node:
                return
            root.parent = parent
			if node.val == start: # if we run into start node we mark it
                self.startNode = node
            addParent(root.left, node)
            addParent(root.right, node)

        def getDist(root, visited) -> int:
			# if reaching the end of the tree, or running into node previously visited, we return 0
            if not root or root.val in visited: 
				return 0
			
			 # add the value into set
			visited.add(root.val)
			# recursively visit left, right, and parent nodes, and return the max
            return 1 + max(getDist(root.left, visited), getDist(root.right, visited), getDist(root.parent, visited)) 
       
        addParent(root, None) #assign parent node for each node in the tree
        dis = getDist(self.startNode, set()) #count the distance to the furthest node

        return dis - 1
```

solutions.content:
STEP-1 : Convert the given tree into the graph (Adjacancy list/Adjacancy Dict; here I have used Dict).
STEP-2: Do BFS traversal and find the count of levels, here the levels signifies the count of seconds.

Time Complexity: O(n), where n is number of nodes.

```
from collections import defaultdict
class Solution:
    def amountOfTime(self, root: Optional[TreeNode], start: int) -> int:
        adj=self.tree_to_graph(root,None,graph=dict())
        res=self.bfs(adj, start)
        return res
            
    def tree_to_graph(self, root, parent, graph):
        graph[root.val] = []
        
        if(root.left != None):
            graph[root.val].append(root.left.val)
            self.tree_to_graph(root.left, root, graph)
            
        if(root.right != None):
            graph[root.val].append(root.right.val)
            self.tree_to_graph(root.right, root, graph)
            
        if(parent != None):
            graph[root.val].append(parent.val)
            
        return graph
    
    def bfs(self, graph, start):
        q=[start]
        visited=set()
        visited.add(start)
        res=0
        while q:
            n=len(q)
            for i in range(len(q)):
                t=q.pop(0)
                for neighbour in graph[t]:
                    if neighbour not in visited:
                        visited.add(neighbour)
                        q.append(neighbour)
            res+=1
        return res-1
```

solutions.content:
# Code
```
class Solution:
    def amountOfTime(self, root: Optional[TreeNode], start: int) -> int:
        self.graph = defaultdict(list)

        # build graph
        def helper(root, parent):
            if not root: return
            if parent != -1:
                self.graph[root.val].append(parent)
                self.graph[parent].append(root.val)
            helper(root.left, root.val)
            helper(root.right, root.val)

        # simple dfs
        self.seen = set()
        self.seen.add(start)
        def dfs(start):
            ret = 0
            for v in self.graph[start]:
                if v in self.seen: continue
                self.seen.add(v)
                ret = max(ret, dfs(v))
            return ret + 1
        
        helper(root, -1)
        return dfs(start)-1
```

solutions.content:
<!-- # Intuition -->
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

<!-- # Approach -->
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

<!-- # Complexity -->
<!-- - Time complexity: -->
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

<!-- - Space complexity: -->
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution {
public:
    TreeNode* createParentMapping(TreeNode* root, int target, map<TreeNode*, TreeNode*> &nodeToParent)
    {
        TreeNode* ans = NULL;
        queue<TreeNode*> q;
        q.push(root);
        nodeToParent[root] = NULL;
        while(!q.empty())
        {
            TreeNode* frontNode = q.front();
            q.pop();
            if(frontNode -> val == target)
                ans = frontNode;
            if(frontNode -> left)
            {
                nodeToParent[frontNode -> left] = frontNode;
                q.push(frontNode -> left);
            }
            if(frontNode -> right)
            {
                nodeToParent[frontNode -> right] = frontNode;
                q.push(frontNode -> right);
            }
        }
        return ans;
    }
    int burnTree(TreeNode* root, map<TreeNode*, TreeNode*> &nodeToParent)
    {
        map<TreeNode*, bool> isVisited;
        queue<TreeNode*> q;
        q.push(root);
        isVisited[root] = true;
        int ans = 0;
        while(!q.empty())
        {
            bool flag = false;
            int size = q.size();
            for(int i = 0; i < size; i++)
            {
                TreeNode* frontNode = q.front();
                q.pop();
                if(frontNode -> left && !isVisited[frontNode -> left])
                {
                    flag = true;
                    q.push(frontNode -> left);
                    isVisited[frontNode -> left] = true;
                }
                if(frontNode -> right && !isVisited[frontNode -> right])
                {
                    flag = true;
                    q.push(frontNode -> right);
                    isVisited[frontNode -> right] = true;
                }
                if(nodeToParent[frontNode] && !isVisited[nodeToParent[frontNode]])
                {
                    flag = true;
                    q.push(nodeToParent[frontNode]);
                    isVisited[nodeToParent[frontNode]] = true;
                }
            }
            if(flag == true)
                ans++;
        }
        return ans;
    }
    int amountOfTime(TreeNode* root, int start) {
        map<TreeNode*, TreeNode*> nodeToParent;
        TreeNode* targetNode = createParentMapping(root, start, nodeToParent);
        return burnTree(targetNode, nodeToParent);
    }
};
```
